row k3 row 4 ws k3 *k1 p1* repeat ** until 3 sts before end of row k3 place a bulb marker to mark the rs repeat row 1-4 until your scarf measures approximately 150cm 60 for a double loop cowl you can adjust the length and number of stitches cast-on to suit your requirements grafting you will now use kitchener stitch to graft the ends of your cowl together there are many online tutorials available for kitchener stitch but there are written instructions below place the stitches from your provisional cast-on on a 4 5 mm us size 7 needle hold your two needles next to each other parallel with the tips facing right and the working yarn on the back needle cut your yarn leaving a tail approximately double to three times the length of row of stitches to be grafted #madebymoomeeno #mwsogl #mwsoglcowl 2 m a d e b y m o o m e e n o kitchener set-up thread your yarn through a tapestry needle and using the tapestry needle go into the first stitch on the front needle as if to purl then into the first stitch on the back needle as if to knit pull your yarn through both stitches leaving the stitches on the needle step 1 continuing with the tapestry needle go through the first stitch on the front needle again but as if to knit this time letting the stitch fall off the needle go through the second stitch on the front needle as if to purl leaving the stitch on the needle step 2 go through the first stitch on the back needle as if to purl letting the stitch fall off the needle go through the second stitch on the back needle as if to knit leaving the stitch on the needle step 3 pull the yarn through the worked stitches firmly making sure no working yarn is looped over the needles step 4 repeat steps 1-3 until all stitches have been worked finishing weave in all ends and wet block to
